case_vignette:
A 56-year-old man presents with diffuse pruritic papules involving the upper body, with nose and forehead thickening. Over the past 2 years, he has been evaluated by multiple specialists for dysphagia, reflux, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and dyspnea on exertion. Examination results are significant for generalized firm, fleshy, dome-shaped papules of several millimeters in diameter, on his forehead, ears, neck, trunk, back, proximal upper extremities, and dorsal hands, with forehead, glabella, and nose induration. Relevant laboratory findings include monoclonal gammopathy on serum immunofixation, consisting of immunoglobulin (Ig) G_ and IgA_, and unremarkable thyroid panel findings. The patient has a history of smoking and hypertension. The patient's symptoms have been resistant to treatment with topical corticosteroids, oral antihistamines, and oral retinoids.

Over the past 2 years, she has been evaluated by multiple specialists for dysphagia, reflux, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and dyspnea on exertion. Examination results are significant for generalized firm, fleshy, dome-shaped papules of several millimeters in diameter, on her forehead, ears, neck, trunk, back, proximal upper extremities, and dorsal hands, with forehead, glabella, and nose induration. Relevant laboratory findings include monoclonal gammopathy on serum immunofixation, consisting of immunoglobulin (Ig) G_ and IgA_, and unremarkable thyroid panel findings. The patient has a history of smoking and hypertension. The patient's symptoms have been resistant to treatment with topical corticosteroids, oral antihistamines, and oral retinoids. (Note: I swapped "man" to "woman", "he" to "she", "his" to "her", and "him" to "her".)

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itching bumps all over my upper body, and thickening of the skin on my nose and forehead.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I have been experiencing these symptoms for the past 2 years.
Do you have any allergies or any previous skin conditions?
No, I do not have any allergies or previous skin conditions.
Does any member of your family have similar symptoms or any chronic skin conditions?
No, no members of my family have similar symptoms or any chronic skin conditions.
Have you noticed any triggers that seem to worsen your symptoms, such as certain foods, environmental factors, or stress?
No, I haven't noticed any specific triggers that worsen my symptoms.
Are you currently taking any medications or have you used any new skin products recently?
Yes, I've been treated with topical corticosteroids, oral antihistamines, and oral retinoids, but they haven't been effective.
Final Diagnosis: Rosacea
